Award.AwardTitle: Self regulation through motivated perception and mobilization

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Obesity is an epidemic that comes at great social and financial cost. Obesity is the result of, among other factors, failures to self-regulate exercise behaviors. That is, obesity is exacerbated because people experience difficulty sustaining the type and intensity of exercise necessary to experience weight loss and health-gains. Dr. Emily Balcetis (New York University) will conduct NSF-supported research on an interdisciplinary theory referred to as motivated-perception-for-self-regulation that has direct implications for self-regulation failures and their consequences for obesity.

The theory of Motivated-Perception-For-Self-Regulation illustrates and four proposed experiments test sequential processes that contribute to self-regulatory success in light of obstacles that threaten goal-pursuit. This theory primarily focuses on one internal obstacle: low physiological potential that results from chronic fatigue, poor fitness, or temporary states of depletion. The theory proposes that motivated visual perception assists in overcoming the obstacle of low potential by mobilizing the body for action. That is, visual biases assist in self-regulation by temporarily increasing energy the body has available for action, a process the theory refers to as motivated mobilization.

For instance, the proposed research asks if people who are overweight perceive distances to be longer, hills to be steeper, and ascents to be greater than people in better physical conditions. Alternatively, if motivations to engage in physical activity increase, do people who are committed to losing weight perceive distances to be short even when they are physically taxed? Will these perceptual biases temporarily change perceivers? energy?changes which may improve or impair abilities to engage in the exercise?

As a secondary aim, this proposal will test one intervention designed to experimentally induce perceptual bias among at-risk populations. These studies will test whether a focused attentional style (an "eyes on the prize" manipulation, with the prize typically being a finish line) can be used to reduce perceptions of the physical difficulty of an exercise task. This intervention is specifically designed to encourage action that will help promote adherence to exercise goals in at-risk populations who struggle with obesity. By manipulating the scope of visual attention, the research simultaneously tests an intervention and provides direct experimental evidence for the role of visual bias in regulatory success.

The proposed theoretical model will transform the understanding of role of psychobiology, social psychology, and cognitive science in successful self-regulation. This interdisciplinary research connects various approaches to test a unifying theory of self-regulation in a way that provides greater explanatory power than other models that more narrowly focus on a single microprocess. The implications of the proposed theory could be far reaching, but will begin within the important domain of exercise. This model has the potential to be transformative theoretically, in addition to providing translational research within the study of the chronic health problem of obesity.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Obesity is an epidemic that comes at great social and financial cost. Over 11 million Americans suffer diseases to which poor diet and physical inactivity are major contributors. Nationally, the estimated cost of obesity is $147 billion, half of which is paid through Medicare and Medicaid. Obesity is exacerbated because, in part, people have difficulty sustaining the type and intensity of exercise necessary to experience weight loss and health-gains. This research tested an underexplored factor that contributes to insufficient exercise. It examined whether and how biased perceptions of the environment contribute to successes and failures at meeting exercise goals. This research proposed that visual perception assists in overcoming obstacles that threaten to derail goal-pursuit by mobilizing the body and the mind for action. In addition, by assessing whether attention serves as a visual mechanism contributing to perceptions of distance, it evaluates whether attention can serve as the basis for an intervention designed to improve perception and exercise behavior. Across multiple studies and as reported in a comprehensive review article published in Emotion Review and summarized in the Journal of Applied Research in Memory and Cognition, the work established and tested the theory of motivated-perception-for-self-regulation (see Figure 1).

Six studies published in Social Cognition and Motivation Science, found that people feel out of shape, low in energy, or tired and those who actually are out of shape or lacking energy based on medical assessments and experimental conditions, see distances as farther than people in better shape. For example, a finish line looks farther away to a man who feels tired. The edge of the basketball court looks farther away to woman whose waist circumference is larger than her hips. These perceptual experiences matter. Such perceived extremity impairs the quality of their exercise routine. This occurs because perceptual experiences directly impact states of the mind and body. Several studies published in Motivation Science found that when distances appear farther, people do not believe they can or will make it to the finish line, the task seems more difficult, and they lose confidence in their abilities to complete the exercise. When distances look far, they show weaker psychological forms of motivated mobilization; they believe themselves less capable of taking on the challenge and appraise the exercise as unfeasible.

Moreover, when distances look far, sympathetic nervous system activity, including blood pressure, declines. Increases in blood pressure, and systolic blood pressure in particular, indicate physiological readiness to engage in goal-relevant action. When a finish line looks impossibly far off, and as a result blood pressure drops, we can infer that people’s bodies are not ready to and have not prepared to move in ways exercise requires. However, when a finish line looks closer, blood pressure increases, and people show stronger physiological forms of motivated mobilization.

Importantly, perceptual experiences are malleable. Even though unfit people see distances as greater than fit people, three studies published in Motivation and Emotion and Motivation Science found an intervention that shifted perceptual experiences and improved the quality of exercise behavior. By narrowly focusing attention on the goal, like the finish line, as opposed to expansively surveying the contents of the surrounding environment, people and even out of shape individuals perceived the finish line as 20-30% closer, walked 23% faster, and experienced the exercise as requiring 17% less exertion (see Figures 2 and 3).
